Fujitsu develops system to prevent accidents caused by leaving objects on the road, tests it in company vehicles | Central Japan Economic News, economic information from Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka

Fujii (headquarters in Kozaki-cho), which handles the production and sales of robots and work machines using electronic parts, has started developing a system to prevent "forgetting" children left in cars.
A system that detects movement using a motion sensor in the car and sends notifications to your phone or chat.
We are currently conducting a trial using our own vehicles.
Keep your children safe even in the event of a painful accident.
Currently, two vehicles are being used for a trial run of a pick-up service for Terakoya THANK, an English conversation school for children, in the city of Kizugawa.
We installed three human-presence sensors, which detect movement based on temperature differences between people and their surroundings, in the ceiling of the car.
If the vehicle engine is turned off and the doors are closed, and after a certain period of time, motion is detected, an alert notification is automatically sent.
By linking engine and door status and information, we can prevent false alarms as much as possible.
The warning messages are broadcast through the cloud.
You can also display it on your computer or smartphone chat.
You can register multiple addresses and take measures to avoid mistakes such as missing deliveries.
The trial will continue until the end of February.
"During the experiment, we were able to see the surrounding issues that are not related to the system," said Kawakami Toshihiko, director of the second section of the Innovation Promotion Department.
For example, it has been able to pick up on a variety of issues related to school buses, such as creating an environment where drivers can concentrate on driving.
"If you expand your solution," he said, "you can do it."
The impetus for developing a parking prevention system was a series of accidents involving school buses that were left unattended across the country.
A suggestion was made by an employee with children to see if there was anything that could be done to ensure the safety of children.

The company decided to develop the technology by applying the know-how it has cultivated through its FA (factory automation) business, such as IoT (Internet of Things) and sensor-based information management.
Fujitsu's anti-theft system is easy to use.
The sensor can be mounted on the ceiling with just a pin.
The company is aiming to lower the barriers to adoption and spread the technology by making it easy to attach to existing shuttle vehicles.
Going forward, we will consider productization while also collaborating with daycare centers and kindergartens.

[Opinion] Oita City is making and distributing ending notes to the citizens who hope for it.

Last year, he published a comprehensive guide to the procedures and forms needed when a loved one dies, including a will, an inventory of assets, a family tree, and more. He says that many people who bought it for themselves also bought it for others.
In the prefecture, there are seminars on how to write an ending note and how to prepare for death in various locations, and "end of life" has become a common topic among the citizens.
The ending note of Oita city is 35 pages long.

The first chapter is a review of your life history, and the following chapters cover your current health status and assets, future care, end-of-life medical care wishes, funeral and graveyard preferences, and so on.
There is also a column for things you want to do in the rest of your life and messages for important people.
I say 35 pages but you don't have to fill them all.
What do you want to write down for your family and the people around you?
The hard part is to make the goal clear.
You can buy a variety of notebooks at bookstores and other places, and you can start writing anywhere you can write.
The term "retirement" was coined when the job market became saturated.
In 2011, two years later, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred.
Many people are facing the reality that "death comes suddenly," and the number of people preparing for their own end of life and end-of-life care is increasing.
It's been 10 years since then.
The new coronavirus pandemic, which has spread around the world, is still not under control.
The price of gas has skyrocketed due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and this winter's electricity bills have reached unimaginable prices.
Half of Americans are worried about their paychecks not keeping up with rising prices.
Meanwhile, the days when children could share the cost of funeral expenses, care fees and graveyard maintenance with their parents are long gone.
Another challenge is that while life expectancy has increased significantly since then, the risk of cognitive decline and need for caregiving increases with age.
In the background of the temporary nature of death, we must remember that there is a high level of social anxiety.
Either way, no one wants to overburden their partner or children.
"Dying with dignity" is a popular keyword for the ending note, but it can't be too self-centered.
I want to talk to my family about it, and prepare myself for that moment, rather than just writing it down secretly.

NPO Corporation "Resonating Collection / Editorial Office" self-published book "Dear Prime Minister, Mr. Abe, "The Levee of Life" from Tou Shikou Fum
"Dear Prime Minister, from Toshimikubo, the bastion of life" I self-published my 10th book with this title.
We have received many letters from readers, and all the newspapers in the country have taken up the story.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the insights of the author, who has directly listened to the reasons for suicide from those who have planned to commit suicide, on the "social and structural" environment that is a cause of suicide in Japan, and to create a society where people can live with a sense of fulfillment.

We have been patrolling the cliffs of Tsukino-hama, Fukui Prefecture, known as a suicide hotspot, for 18 years and 10 months, providing support to prevent suicide attempts by discovering and protecting those who are planning to jump, and helping them to return to safety.

This book is a compilation of the issues raised by the 784 people (2/6 currently) who have been protected so far, and we are presenting the following seven items to the Prime Minister as necessary measures to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life saving" activities.
(2) Behind suicide, there is a mountain of "human rights violations".
(3) Suicides are victims of social and structural organized crime.
(4) Administrative agencies are treating citizens who live outside the jurisdiction as "outsiders" and are cold-shouldering them.
(5) Mental illness patients are drugged and killed, and it is treated as an "accident".
(6) The "duty of care" in high-risk suicide areas is being forgotten and commercialism is running rampant.

The city is asking for the process to return the items while apologizing and explaining the circumstances to the affected individuals.
The city discovered the problem after being alerted by the guardians of the children who received the payments in the past.
The government confirmed that 12 households out of 182 households eligible for the same year's subsidies received double payments on July 20, 2020, during the Reiwa 3rd year.
The city will provide a subsidy of 50,000 yen per child for households that do not pay the local inhabitant tax and have children under high school age.

The "Eniwa Airport Carbon Neutral Promotion Agreement" (Chairman: Ando Tatsuo, Chief of the Construction Division of the Hokkaido Prefecture Oshima Office, members: 13), which is composed of the prefecture and airlines that use Eniwa Airport to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.

The target setting for decarbonization and the exchange of opinions on the introduction of renewable energy with solar power as the main subject were conducted.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a target to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions of each airport by 46% or more within 30 years, in order to achieve "carbon neutrality" by 2050.

According to the distribution materials, the CO2 emissions of the same airport facilities and vehicles in the base year of 2013 were 14,760 tons (excluding aircraft).

Among these, the lighting and air conditioning of seven facilities, including the airport terminal building, account for about 90% of the 1,321 tons, followed by the airport's lighting of 841 tons and airport vehicles of 710 tons.
The council is discussing reducing emissions from these facilities and vehicles.

Sakasama Real Estate, a real estate web service that visualizes the thoughts of people who want to try something like renting a vacant house or store, held an opening event for its Shibuya branch on the 8th at the well-known community space "entaku" in Shibuya.
The operator company explains the overview of the service in the talk session.

"If we can attract people to the island by doing this initiative in Oki-Echizen, we can create a flow of people to the island," said Takahashi Masahiro, president of Tugino Bank (Tsuruga-shi, Fukui Prefecture), which operates the branch.
Peer-to-peer real estate is the opposite of normal real estate, where you disclose information about yourself to the landlord and negotiate with them if you agree, and then contract on your own.
As a real experiment to discover vacant houses and to build relationships through vacant houses, the company ONC-O (head office in Mie prefecture) started the service in June 2020.
This is the seventh branch to be opened, and the first in Kyushu.
It's the first in the country on an island.
About 20 people, including On-Coe and staff of Tugino-ba, residents of Wadabu and staff of the town office and the famous town, participated in the event.

Mr. Okubo, the representative director, explained the background of the branch office opening, saying, "I thought that if we could make use of vacant houses and vacant shops while the movement of inviting people from outside the island is becoming active, the town and the island will become more prosperous."
"We want to connect with people who have property on the island or want to do something with the island, and help them in any way we can with their projects," he said.

"It is necessary to discuss how to use the empty houses one by one, and how the local people want to develop the area, who they want to attract, and what criteria they will use," said Ono Takashi, the representative of the Ono-Cohousing group, pointing out the issues that need to be addressed in the operation.
"The more connections you have with people, the more information you'll get," he told the islanders, urging them to participate in the discussions and share information.
